newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian govt members support tax reform.
newsitem.headline: Australian govt members support tax reform.

text.p: A campaign to overhaul the Australian taxation system was launched on Monday when junior members of the conservative government gave their overwhelming support for Prime Minister John Howard's reform plans.
But proposed changes remained broad and backbenchers had not considered specific options such as a consumption tax in any depth during a late night meeting with Liberal-National coalition leaders.

"The coalition parties expressed a genuine desire for tax reform, very strong support for general tax reform and gave a steer to the Prime Minister and the Cabinet about the way in which the issue should be progressed," Treasurer Peter Costello told reporters after the meeting.
He said backbenchers were aware of the inconsistencies of the tax system and believed that any reforms should be aimed at boosting the economy.
"There's a very strong view that tax reform has got to be focused on increasing exports and developing jobs," Costello said.

Prime Minister John Howard last month said there was a need for a debate on the tax system and revamped the push for a controversial goods and services tax (GST) that many blame for delaying the coalition's return to power.

The coalition -- which lost what was regarded as an unloseable election in 1993 with a policy for a GST -- pledged in the 1996 election not to introduce a consumption tax in its first three-year term.
But a series of recent opinion polls have showed growing community support for a GST and Howard has not ruled out its introduction in the second term of government.
Backbenchers said some parliamentarians remained concerned about the impacts of a GST policy at the next election, although the majority seemed to support it.
"I'd say there was a number of people who still have the experience of 1993 fresh in their minds," backbencher Ross Cameron told Reuters.
"I don't think there's strong opposition to a GST per se, but there are serious questions about how we enrol the community in that discussion."
Costello said government members were encouraged to seek community opinion on the issue and report back to the government before the next step was taken.
